Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Consortium at the 2018 International Conference on Robotics and Automation (ICRA)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides funds to partially support U.S. Ph.D. students working in robotics the opportunity to attend a Doctoral Consortium at the International Conference on Robotics and Automation (ICRA), one of the major international robotics conferences. The conference, to be held May 21-25, 2018 in Brisbane, Australia, attracts an international audience that includes academics, industry, entrepreneurs, and funding agency leaders.

Participation in the Doctoral Consortium will enable the students to share their knowledge and interact with each other and with senior researchers outside their own institutions, to learn about different sub-fields within robotics, to understand industry needs, and to become apprised of new technology that will be demonstrated by vendors. The Doctoral Consortium includes an afternoon of activities, including oral and poster presentations by students, focused breakout sessions, a keynote address, and two panels led by researchers in academia and industry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project supported the participation of US-based PhD students in a doctoral consortium (also referred to as the PhD Forum) at the 2018 International Conference on Robotics and Automation (ICRA), which took place in Brisbane, Australia in May 2018. ICRA is a premier international conference for the robotics community, attended by thousands of researchers from academia and industry.

The doctoral consortium included panel discussions on careers in academia and industry as well as a panel on future robotics research directions. The panels were lead by several senior members of the community, including Peter Corke (Queensland University of Technology), Dieter Fox (University of Washington/NVIDIA), Ayanna Howard (Georgia Institute of Technology), Lydia Kavraki (Rice University), Paul Newman (Oxford University/Oxbotica), and Allison Okamura (Stanford University). Student participants then had the opportunity to present their research and to get feedback from these mentors during an interactive poster session. This was followed by a roundtable discussion on the future of robotics between participants and their mentors.

In order to participate in the consortium, students were required to submit an application that included a two-page CV and a two-page abstract that summarized their research, highlighted important related work, and described current results. Applications were reviewed by a selection committee that included the consortium organizers. Among those accepted for participation in the consortium, applicants registered as full-time students at higher education institutions in the US were considered for support under this grant. Particular attention was paid to students from underrepresented groups as well as to students from smaller institutions, who may not have the same mentorship opportunities as students from larger programs. In total, 38 doctoral students participated in the consortium, of which 18 US-based students received funding through this grant to support their attendance. Of these, eight students identified as female, and two as racial minorities.

Participation in both the doctoral consortium and in ICRA provided US-based PhD students with the opportunity to interact with a broad range of researchers and educators, helping to establish their membership in the robotics community. Importantly, the consortium provided participants with experience presenting their research and with a unique opportunity for research and career mentorship from senior members of the community. Support from this grant was particularly helpful in supporting students from US-based institutions given the cost of traveling to Brisbane, Australia.
